body:
Comment 4 by **czapkofan**: 
I also suspected these may be some pre-ANSI rules, but given that, I dare to suggest
this might be very non-obvious to many people hacking on the Go's C codebase, those
amusing youngsters (sub)consciously assuming this funny new ANSI-thing. And thus, I
would kindly ask to at least insert some temporary "print(WARNING_TAG)" in some code
uniquely triggered for this behavior, and then build Go (ideally for all platforms) and
verify that there are no cases when WARNING_TAG gets printed. And if there are, then
review these parts of code in light of this behavior. And actually, it might still be a
good idea to leave this WARNING_TAG in code permanently, based on the non-obviousness.
